content.title: Proteinuria Evaluation
content.summary: Proteinuria is a key marker of kidney disease requiring systematic evaluation to quantify, categorize, and identify the underlying cause. The workup distinguishes albuminuria from other protein types, uses spot urine protein-to-creatinine ratio (UPCR) or albumin-to-creatinine ratio (UACR) for quantification, and guides further investigation based on the pattern and severity.
key_points: Spot UACR or UPCR correlates well with 24-hour collection; first morning void is most accurate
Albuminuria ≥30 mg/g (A2) indicates kidney damage even with normal GFR
Nephrotic-range proteinuria: >3.5 g/day or UPCR >3500 mg/g
Always rule out orthostatic proteinuria in young patients (<30 years)
Proteinuria reduction is a therapeutic target to slow CKD progression
SPEP/UPEP if light chain disease suspected (overflow proteinuria)
content.statement: Proteinuria evaluation is a structured diagnostic approach to detect, quantify, and characterize urinary protein excretion, distinguishing albuminuria from overflow and tubular proteinuria to guide diagnosis and management of kidney disease.

explanation.intuition: The glomerular filtration barrier normally blocks proteins by size and charge. Proteinuria indicates this barrier is damaged (glomerular leak), tubules failed to reabsorb filtered proteins (tubular), or excess proteins overwhelmed normal reabsorption (overflow). Each pattern has different causes and implications.
explanation.key_insight: Albuminuria (measured by UACR) is the most clinically relevant because it specifically reflects glomerular damage and is an independent cardiovascular risk factor. The A1/A2/A3 staging integrates with GFR (G1-5) to risk-stratify CKD prognosis.
explanation.technical_details: Normal albumin excretion is <30 mg/day. The dipstick detects albumin ≥300 mg/L but misses microalbuminuria. UACR on spot urine (preferably first AM void) correlates r=0.97 with 24h collection. Sulfosalicylic acid precipitates all proteins including light chains.

definitions_glossary.proteinuria: Abnormal excretion of protein in urine; >150 mg/day total protein
definitions_glossary.albuminuria: Abnormal excretion of albumin; marker of glomerular damage
definitions_glossary.microalbuminuria: Albumin 30-300 mg/day; now termed moderately increased albuminuria (A2)
definitions_glossary.nephrotic_range_proteinuria: Protein excretion >3.5 g/day or UPCR >3500 mg/g
definitions_glossary.UACR: Urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio; expressed as mg/g
definitions_glossary.UPCR: Urine protein-to-creatinine ratio; estimates 24h protein in g/day
definitions_glossary.orthostatic_proteinuria: Benign proteinuria present only when upright; absent in first AM void
definitions_glossary.overflow_proteinuria: Excess filtered protein (e.g., light chains) exceeding tubular reabsorption
definitions_glossary.tubular_proteinuria: Low-molecular-weight proteins from impaired tubular reabsorption
definitions_glossary.glomerular_proteinuria: Albumin-predominant from damaged glomerular filtration barrier
definitions_glossary.selectivity_index: IgG:albumin clearance ratio; <0.1 suggests selective (minimal change disease)
definitions_glossary.SPEP: Serum protein electrophoresis; detects monoclonal proteins

pathophysiology.mechanism: Protein appears in urine when glomerular barrier fails, tubular reabsorption is impaired, or filtered load exceeds capacity

glomerular.mechanism: Damage to glomerular basement membrane or podocytes increases permeability
glomerular.protein_type: Primarily albumin (67 kDa); selectivity indicates minimal change vs FSGS

tubular.mechanism: Impaired proximal tubule reabsorption of filtered low-molecular-weight proteins
tubular.protein_type: Beta-2 microglobulin, retinol-binding protein, alpha-1 microglobulin

overflow.mechanism: Excessive production of small proteins overwhelms normal tubular reabsorption

functional.mechanism: Transient proteinuria without structural kidney disease

dipstick.limitations: Misses microalbuminuria; false positives with concentrated/alkaline urine

spot_UPCR.interpretation: mg protein/g creatinine approximates g/day total protein

essential_workup: Spot UACR or UPCR on first morning void
Repeat positive result to confirm persistent proteinuria
Split specimen (AM/PM) if orthostatic proteinuria suspected

differential_diagnosis: Diabetic kidney disease (most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults)

general_principles: Target proteinuria reduction as key therapeutic goal

ACE_inhibitors_ARBs.indication: First-line for proteinuric CKD and diabetic nephropathy
ACE_inhibitors_ARBs.target: Reduce proteinuria by >50% or to <0.5 g/day

SGLT2_inhibitors.mechanism: Reduce glomerular hyperfiltration independent of glucose
SGLT2_inhibitors.indication: CKD with proteinuria regardless of diabetes

finerenone.indication: Diabetic kidney disease with residual albuminuria on RAASi

dietary: Sodium restriction <2 g/day enhances ACE-I/ARB effect
Moderate protein intake 0.8 g/kg/day in CKD

definition.@value: A systematic diagnostic approach to detect, quantify, and characterize urinary protein excretion for diagnosis and management of kidney disease

scopeNote.@value: Covers evaluation of all types of proteinuria including albuminuria screening, quantification methods, and interpretation in CKD staging

learning_objectives: Classify proteinuria by pathophysiology: glomerular, tubular, overflow, functional
Use UACR and UPCR to quantify proteinuria from spot urine specimens
Apply KDIGO albuminuria staging (A1-A3) to risk-stratify CKD
Identify indications for nephrology referral based on proteinuria severity
Select appropriate antiproteinuric therapy including ACE-I, ARB, and SGLT2i
clinical_pearls: First morning void UACR is most accurate (avoids orthostatic contribution)
Dipstick misses light chains - use sulfosalicylic acid or UPEP if myeloma suspected
Nephrotic syndrome = proteinuria >3.5g/day + hypoalbuminemia + edema + hyperlipidemia
A2 albuminuria (30-300 mg/g) is an independent CV risk factor even without GFR decline
Target 50% proteinuria reduction - each doubling increases ESRD risk 3-fold
common_misconceptions: 24-hour collection is always needed - spot UACR/UPCR is adequate for most purposes
1+ dipstick protein is always significant - may be false positive with concentrated urine
Orthostatic proteinuria needs treatment - it is benign and requires only reassurance

citations.authors: KDIGO 2012 Clinical Practice Guideline for the Evaluation and Management of CKD
citations.title: Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) CKD Work Group

evidence.confidence_rationale: Based on KDIGO guidelines for CKD staging and proteinuria evaluation

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill, 2022.
